awd_titl_txt: Control and Stabilization of Mechanical Systems with Broken Symmetry via Symmetry Recovery
awd_abstract_narration:
Many mechanical or robotic systems are designed to operate in a specific configuration or position. For example, an underwater vehicle must maintain a certain attitude to carry out its missions such as underwater surveillance or an offshore wind turbine must maintain its upright position under various disturbances created by waves and gusts in the ocean. However, such a configuration tends to be naturally unstable under external disturbances, and hence must be controlled properly to stay in a desired configuration. The main objective of this project is to innovate new control strategies to stabilize and control such difficult-to-control systems, exploiting some inherent dynamic characteristics of these systems. The new control strategies will be applicable to a wide class of mechanical and robotic systems as opposed to ad-hoc techniques that are currently used which are designed for a specific system. The project involves a group of students from diverse backgrounds and academic levels, and integrates research with outreach activities using a simple and easy to understand robotic system.   

Mechanical and robotic systems under the influence of gravity or buoyancy can be seen as systems with broken symmetry: The presence of the external forces introduces a particular direction along which the force applies to the system, thereby breaking the symmetry that the system would otherwise possess. Balancing or stabilizing such systems by applying controls to them has been one of the main challenges in control theory. The project develops a new paradigm of control and stabilization of mechanical systems with broken symmetry. Building on the differential-geometric formulation of Lagrangian/Hamiltonian systems with broken symmetry, the project aims to develop a general theory of stabilization that applies to mechanical and robotic systems under the influence of gravity/buoyancy. The project broadens the scope of applications of stabilization techniques developed for mechanical systems by systematically extending the method of controlled Lagrangians/Hamiltonians to systems with broken symmetry. The methods will also be generalized to those mechanical systems under nonholonomic constraints as well, further extending the scope of applications to those robotic systems with rolling and sliding constraints as well as underwater vehicles with velocity constraints.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Many mechanical and robotic systems must operate in specific positions or configurations under the influence of external forces such as the gravity, buoyancy, and some other form of constraints. However, these external influences usually break the symmetry of the system they would otherwise possess. More specifically, the absence of such a force implies that the surrounding environment of the system is uniform and hence has no special direction in it---hence implying a symmetry, whereas the presence such an external force introduces a particular direction along which the force applies to the system---hence breaking the symmetry.

This project developed methods to stabilize those systems under such symmetry-breaking external influences. The motivating examples of practical interest were an underwater vehicle and a simple model of a figure skater as shown in figures. An underwater vehicle lacks rotational symmetry if the centers of gravity and buoyancy are non-coincident, because rotations about one of the centers is influenced by the other force. A pendulum attached to a skate sliding on an ice rink---a simple model for a figure skater---lacks rotational symmetry as well, because both the gravity and the rink introduce special directions in the otherwise uniform and symmetric environment.

These external influences often render the systems unstable too. The steady straight motions of a bottom-heavy underwater vehicle have been known to be unstable under some circumstances: A small perturbation may result in unruly rotations of the vehicle as shown in a figure. The same goes with the steady straight motions and slow spinning motions (with less than a certain angular velocity) of the figure skater model: The skater must apply a certain form of control to herself mainly with her arms to maintain her position during such motions.

The project has broadened the scope of applications of existing stabilization techniques developed for mechanical systems by systematically extending the method of controlled Lagrangians to systems with broken symmetry, including those systems with symmetry-breaking nonholonomic constraints (such as rolling and sliding constraints).

The newly developed method applied to the underwater vehicle is proven to stabilize the otherwise unstable steady straight motions of the bottom-heavy underwater vehicle: One can see that the motion is almost straight maintaining its orientation almost upright as shown in a figure. The method extended for nonholonomic systems is also proven to stabilize both the sliding and spinning equilibria of the figure skater model by using a momentum wheel attached to the body (pendulum) of the skater.

The project also contained some exploratory studies including (i) a reformulation of non-canonical mechanical systems into a canonical one so that the standard techniques developed for canonical systems apply to non-canonical systems including some systems with broken symmetry, (ii) an application of the equations of motion for mechanical systems with broken symmetry to optimization problems, and (iii) a preliminary study on how to control a rolling spherical robot.
